channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: CDC director is out after less than a month; other agency leaders resign
item.description: "Susan Monarez is no longer director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention," the Department of Health and Human Services wrote in a social media post. Her lawyers said she had neither resigned nor been told she was fired.
item.content:encoded:
"Susan Monarez is no longer director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention," the Department of Health and Human Services wrote in a social media post. Her lawyers said she had neither resigned nor been told she was fired.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Colleges see significant drop in international students as fall semester begins
item.description: Delays and increased screenings for visas mean that many students didn't make it to campus on time – and that has some big implications for the economy.
item.content:encoded: Delays and increased screenings for visas mean that many students didn't make it to campus on time – and that has some big implications for the economy.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: The latest COVID vaccines come with new FDA limits
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the next round of COVID-19 vaccines, but is restricting them to people at high risk for COVID complications.
item.content:encoded:
The Food and Drug Administration approved the next round of COVID-19 vaccines, but is restricting them to people at high risk for COVID complications.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Brands are loving Taylor Swift's engagement. Do they need to calm down?
item.description: Companies from Pillsbury to Invisalign to Olipop are cheering — and trying to cash in on — the couple's engagement. Experts spoke to NPR about how brands can strike a better balance.
item.content:encoded:
Companies from Pillsbury to Invisalign to Olipop are cheering — and trying to cash in on — the couple's engagement. Experts spoke to NPR about how brands can strike a better balance.

(Image credit: Ezra Shaw)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Greetings from the Negev desert, where traces remain of a vanished ancient civilization
item.description: Far-Flung Postcards is a weekly series in which NPR's international team shares moments from their lives and work around the world.
item.content:encoded: Far-Flung Postcards is a weekly series in which NPR's international team shares moments from their lives and work around the world.
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: Shooting during Mass at Minnesota Catholic school leaves 2 dead, 17 others injured
item.description: The shooter fired through the windows of Annunciation Church during Mass on Wednesday before dying from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, said Minneapolis Police Chief Brian O'Hara.
item.content:encoded:
The shooter fired through the windows of Annunciation Church during Mass on Wednesday before dying from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, said Minneapolis Police Chief Brian O'Hara.

(Image credit: Alex Kormann)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: Take The Planet Money Summer School Quiz In Political Economy
item.description: Think you have what it takes to successfully manipulate the market and build a domestic industry from the ground up? If so, these eight questions stand between you and your Summer School diploma in Political Economy.
item.content:encoded: Think you have what it takes to successfully manipulate the market and build a domestic industry from the ground up? If so, these eight questions stand between you and your Summer School diploma in Political Economy.
item.dc:creator: Eric Mennel

item.title: Whatever happened to our sibling series? It's back! And guess who's the heir apparent
item.description: When parents die, sibling tensions can arise over inheritance. In many traditions, the oldest child used to get it all. In a part of Pakistan, there's a surprise twist: The youngest is the chosen one.
item.content:encoded:
When parents die, sibling tensions can arise over inheritance. In many traditions, the oldest child used to get it all. In a part of Pakistan, there's a surprise twist: The youngest is the chosen one.

(Image credit: Shayan Ali Khan)
item.dc:creator: Benazir Samad

item.title: Fed governor fights for her job. And, the DNC has a message for Democrats
item.description: Fed Governor Lisa Cook plans to fight to keep her job with a forthcoming lawsuit challenging President Trump. And, the DNC addresses the Democratic Party's challenges.
item.content:encoded:
Fed Governor Lisa Cook plans to fight to keep her job with a forthcoming lawsuit challenging President Trump. And, the DNC addresses the Democratic Party's challenges.

(Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: A 6-year-old girl from Gaza, a missing limb and a doctor's mission
item.description: How do you heal the wounds of war? That is the mission of Dr. Ghassan Abu-Sittah, a reconstructive and plastic surgeon at the American University of Beirut Medical Center.
item.content:encoded:
How do you heal the wounds of war? That is the mission of Dr. Ghassan Abu-Sittah, a reconstructive and plastic surgeon at the American University of Beirut Medical Center.

(Image credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel
